results.adx_keywords: Royal Families;Edward, Duke of Edinburgh (1964- );Charles III, King of the United Kingdom;Rhys-Jones, Sophie;Great Britain
results.title: Prince Edward Receives a New Title on His Birthday
results.abstract: King Charles III named Edward, his youngest brother, the Duke of Edinburgh on his 59th birthday. The title was previously held by their father, Prince Philip.
per_facet: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom

media.caption: Prince Edward, Prince Philip and Edward’s wife, Sophie, in 2016. Edward has been granted his father’s former title, the Duke of Edinburgh.
media.copyright: Press Association, via Associated Press Images

results.title: ‘Now He Must Pay:’ Kristin Smart’s Killer Is Sentenced to 25 Years to Life

results.title: Saudi Arabia Offers Its Price to Normalize Relations With Israel

results.title: Silicon Valley Bank Fails After Run on Deposits
results.abstract: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation took control of the bank’s assets on Friday. The failure raised concerns that other banks could face problems, too.

results.title: La Niña Has Ended, and El Niño May Be on the Way
results.abstract: The climate pattern that tends to bring drier, warmer conditions to the southern half of the United States and wetter weather to the northern half has ended, NOAA said Thursday.

results.title: Former Ohio Legislator Found Guilty of Racketeering in $60 Million Scheme
results.abstract: Larry Householder, a former Ohio House speaker, and Matthew Borges, a former chairman of the Ohio Republican Party, were found guilty in a conspiracy that dated back to 2017, the Justice Department said.

media.caption: Larry Householder, the former Ohio House speaker, was found guilty in a racketeering conspiracy and faces a maximum prison sentence of 20 years.

results.adx_keywords: Colleges and Universities;Museums;Art;Finances;O'Keeffe, Georgia;Church, Frederic;Hassam, Childe;Valparaiso University;Indiana
results.title: Its Georgia O’Keeffe Is Worth Millions. And Its Dorms Need Updating.
results.abstract: In the face of declining enrollment, Valparaiso University in Indiana wants to raise money to renovate two dormitories by selling treasures from its art museum. Not everyone is on board.

media.caption: “The problem is that the whole process has been secret,” said John Ruff, left, a former English professor opposed to Valparaiso’s plan to sell paintings. Richard Brauer, right, a former art professor whom the school’s museum is named after, said, “It really does outrage me.”
media.copyright: Taylor Glascock for The New York Times
